body.p: The Board’s first consideration when setting the scope of the amendments to IAS 41 was whether to follow a ‘no-alternative-use’ model or a ‘predominant-use’ model. The Board observed that many types of livestock that are used as bearer biological assets by an entity also have a common alternative use as a consumable biological asset. For example, an entity may choose to rear a sheep for its wool (bearer attribute) and/or for its meat (consumable attribute). It was also observed that some trees are cultivated both for their lumber, for example, for furniture production (consumable attribute) and for their fruit (bearer attribute).
